titleStmt.title: The plott and progresse of the Irish rebellion. Wherein is discovered the Machavilian policie of the Earle of Straford, Sir George Ratcliffe and others. Shewing what countenance that rebellion hath had against the Protestants of England, (which doth now too manifestly appeare) by his Majesties granting a free and generall pardon to the rebells in Ireland. And authorizing the calling of a new Parliament in Ireland, according to the rebells desires, of late condiscended unto at Oxford. Printed and published according to order.
titleStmt.author: Crant, Thomas.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The plott and progresse of the Irish rebellion. Wherein is discovered the Machavilian policie of the Earle of Straford, Sir George Ratcliffe and others. Shewing what countenance that rebellion hath had against the Protestants of England, (which doth now too manifestly appeare) by his Majesties granting a free and generall pardon to the rebells in Ireland. And authorizing the calling of a new Parliament in Ireland, according to the rebells desires, of late condiscended unto at Oxford. Printed and published according to order.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Ireland -- History -- Rebellion of 1641 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: THE PLOTT AND PROGRESSE OF THE JRISH REBELLION.
WHEREIN Is di≈øcovered the Machavilian Policie of the Earle of Straford, Sir George Ratcliffe and others.

Shewing what Countenance that Rebellion hath had again≈øt the Prote≈øtants of England, (which doth now too manife≈øtly appeare) by his Maje≈øties granting a free and generall Pardon to the Rebells in Ireland.
And Authorizing the Calling of a New Parliament in Ireland, according to the Rebells de≈øires. of late Condi≈øcended unto at Oxford.

p.hi: Printed and Publ≈øhed according to Order.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by I. N. for Henry Twyford at the three Daggers in Fleet-≈øtreet, 1644.

div.head: THE PLOTT And Progre≈ø≈øe of the Iri≈øh REBELLION.
div.p: LOoke into all Machavillian Pollicies they fir≈øt pretend unto a ≈øeeming good; as may appeare in the Goverment of Ireland, under the Lord Lievtenant Straford, in his fir≈øt comming to regulate the ≈øword, with an au≈øtere hand of Ju≈øtice over all, ≈øeeming to befriend, and ea≈øe the Subjects from a letigious cour≈øe of Law, and Monopolized the major part of Cau≈øes, and reduced them to an Arbitrary Government.

2. The advantage rai≈øed unto his Maje≈øty by affording agreater Revenue for the cu≈øtomes of Ireland, then formerly was given, and ≈øo a grant of farming the cu≈øtomes was afforded ('twas ≈øaid to Sir George Ratclife) the world may be ≈øatisfied
for who≈øe u≈øe it was, then pre≈øently cu≈øtomes were enhanced, of all forts, as Yarne. Tallow, Hide Butter &c. and e≈øpecially Tobacco from ≈øix pence, to two ≈øhillings in the pound, by which increa≈øed an e≈øtate by any unju≈øt exaction from the Subject.

3. In obtaining thirty thou≈øand Arms, Ammunition, Artillery, &c. pretending for the ≈øecurity of the Kingdome, then the confi≈øcating of the lands of Conaught to bring them to the Crowne as al≈øo divers other E≈øtats, in that Kingdome, by which it might ≈øeeme to his Maje≈øty and the ≈øtate of England, good ≈øervice done to the Crowne, it cannot be denied but that the ≈øaid Lord Lievtenant, ≈øhewed him≈øelfe very ≈øevere again≈øt the Natives, neither were the Briti≈øh much favoured, when they came under his hand: This is but a preamble for their intended project.

Touching matters regulated in the Church it is worth a con≈øideration, what innovations were crept in and in the regulating of Eccle≈øia≈øticall iuri≈ødiction, as the High Commi≈ø≈øion Court, &. 'tis worth ob≈øervation, that what power the Bi≈øhop of Derry, Bramble in clawing and never ending for „Äà‚óä„Äâ not onely his fellow Soveraign Bi≈øhops, but al≈øo Arch Bi≈øhops, to void tennants e≈øtats, and enhancing rents nigh the double value what formerly they were, this may conduce ‚Ä¢ o a Romi≈øh pollicy, to keepe the Subject as poore as may be, that when time ≈øerves to inact farther, and impo≈øe on them „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ they plea≈øe; ≈øo the tennants as the Tribe of J≈ø≈øachar, mu≈øt ‚Ä¢ eare what Levi would impo≈øe on them, in a temporall Government, as al≈øo the high Commi≈ø≈øion Court being ≈øo prevalent (that Hillary Tearme la≈øt 1643. at Dublin) in which Doctor Harding was cen≈øured, to be degraded of his mini≈øteriall function and al≈øo of his degrees in the Colledge and after to be left to be proceeded again≈øt at Common Law: the cau≈øe alleadged was for maintaining, Bla≈øphemy in the Colledge about foure yeares ≈øince, alleadging he ≈øhould declare that 'twas inju≈øtice in God to condemne Adam for eating the apple, another charge there was laid again≈øt
him, for cau≈øing a booke to be printed in Dub lin (though he had the approbation of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Dublin) entituled Irelands advocate, being none of his owne worke, but ≈øent by an acquaintance of his from England in manu≈øcript, and he putting it to the pre≈ø≈øe, with an Epi≈øtle Dedicated to Sir Iohn Temple, of his owne framing, in which booke they picke forth trea≈øon (as they tearme it) the fir≈øt exception is becau≈øe the Authour is invective again≈øt Bi≈øhops, the other was in an other place of the booke, giving the Almighty thankes for the ≈øeverall deliverances that England hath had, from the plots of the Papi≈øts, as in≈øtancing that of 88. and that of the 5. of November and that of the 4. of Ianuary, at which of the 4. of Ianuary they ≈øtorme, and inferre, to be trea≈øon, interpreting that was the day his Maje≈øty with his attendance went to demand the five members forth of the hou≈øe of Parliament, and therefore conceived trea≈øon, for rancking or comparing that day to the known Papi≈øticall plotts, and for ought as yet is known he is like to loo≈øe his life: and the bookes that could be found printed were adjudged by the ≈øaid high Commi≈ø≈øion Court, to be burnt by the hand of the hangman; which accordingly was done: This is not the bondage aymed at, but one far deeper the ≈øpirituall bondage of the ≈øoule; as looke into that Cozen-jerman to plaine Popery, Super≈øtitious and Alter-like Service how it was enforced throughout that Kingdome of Ireland and they that refu≈øed, how ≈øeverely they were handled in the high Commi≈ø≈øion Court, 'tis two well known, that divers Mini≈øters that refu≈øed that way were forced to quit that Kingdome, e≈øpecially ≈øome in the North.

Power being once prevalent, both in State and Church, then time ≈øerved to ≈øet forward that Diabolicall plot, for the ruine and de≈øtruction of the Prote≈øtant Religion in the three Kingdomes of England, Scotland, and e≈øpecially Ireland, and the fir≈øt practice (as well 'tis ob≈øerved by the authour of the Booke intituled The My≈øterie of iniquitie yet working) Scotland, (not re≈øenting to what the Prelates would have forced in their
Church) tooke Armes to defend their Religion: a Pa≈ø≈øification was ye ‚Ä¢ lded to by his Maje≈øtie, till after invited by the Earle of Strafford, and others, to take armes De nove: hee having prepared matters ≈øufficiently in Ireland, pretending again≈øt the Scots, and ≈øo drew downe an Armie of eight thou≈øand, (of which 'tis well knowne of Officers, and ≈øouldiers, there were not nigh one thou≈øand Prote≈øtants) to the Scotti≈øh ≈øhoare, where the inhabitant Scot of that Kingdome of Ireland, was by his Commands di≈øarmed, and Garri≈øons planted from Strankford to London-Derrie along the ≈øhoare-≈øide. Matters then beginning to come to a ripene≈ø≈øe, the Earle of Straford brought with him into that Kingdome of Ireland, at his la≈øt going over, one Sir Toby Mathews an arch Je≈øuite, made him his Comrade, (ob≈øerved) none was more honoured by him then this grand Je≈øuite: Now ob≈øerve how ea≈øie a matter it is for a Je≈øuite once under≈øtanding the intent, to ≈øtate the hearts of other Je≈øuites, Friers, Seminaries, &c. and then how ea≈øie a matter, 'tis for them to ≈øtate the hearts of all their people, and adherents, any man may judge that knoweth any thing.

So then if the Lord Strafford did ≈øhew him≈øelfe never ≈øo great a Tyrant (as certaine hee did) not only to the Natives, but al≈øo to the Britti≈øh; the rather to ca≈øt a cloud before the State of England then otherwayes; how ea≈øie it was for the Je≈øuites, Prie≈øts, &c. to informe the Common people, that hee was for all their good, though hee ≈øhewed him≈øelfe otherwayes to them, as time hath brought it forth.

Wee may now evidently ≈øee, what his Plott (with others was,) as I hope to produce ≈øuch conducing Circum≈øtances as may ≈øatisfie the hearts of all good Chri≈øtians, for others that are or may bee of the ≈øame faction, I leave, for who are blinder then they that will not ≈øee. A Mini≈øter who lived in the County of Kildare in Ireland, had ≈øome Conference with a Popi≈øh Prie≈øt living not farre from him, who informed the Mini≈øter, of a Plott that was contrived beyond Sea again≈øt the Prote≈øtants in Ireland, relating that the Iri≈øh intended to ri≈øe ≈øhortly, and
that he had ≈øeen Letters to that purpo≈øe from beyond ≈øea, and that tho≈øe letters were in ≈øuch a Clo≈øet, with ≈øuch a Je≈øuite, in ≈øuch a mans hou≈øe, naming every particular; this was about Aprill 1639. The Mini≈øter finding the Prie≈øt ≈øerious, went along with him to the Earle of Straford, to the Ca≈øtle of Dublin, waited his opportunitie in the Gallerie, and at la≈øt pre≈øented this Prie≈øt to the ≈øaid Earle, expre≈ø≈øing that hee had informed him of a Plott the Papi≈øts had again≈øt the Prote≈øtants; the Earle an≈øwered, 'twas ≈øome bu≈øie-pated knave or other; being urged, he could ≈øay much, replyed; what could he ≈øay? the Prie≈øt being taken privately by the Earle to the further end of the Gallerie, after halfe an houres ≈øpace was di≈ømi≈øt, there was given him by his Lord≈øhips Command, twenty pounds, a hor≈øe, and a ≈øuite of clothes to conceale the matter, and Commanded never to appeare againe, which according to his Commands was obeyed.

Time began to draw on, the Earle of Straford was to returne to England, but before hee went was plea≈øed to expre≈ø≈øe, that if ever hee returned to regulate that honourable Sword againe, hee would leave neither roote, nor branch, of the Scotti≈øh Nation in that Kingdome. Well, over hee goeth to the North of England, where hee intended the ≈øtroake ≈øhould be ≈øtrooke betweene the Armies, it plea≈øed God to prevent, beyond the Expectation of men. The Earle was taken notice of, and according to his merit was requited; Is this all? No, as now 'tis evident by the relation of ≈øome Iri≈øh Je≈øuites, and others, that as ≈øoone as the ≈øtroake was ≈øtrooke by the Armies, betweene England and Scotland, (which was to be about Michaelma≈ø≈øe 1640.) the Earle of Straford was to returne for Ireland, then was it, that the Iri≈øh Armie being drawn down to the North as afore≈øaid, was to fall upon all the Inhabitants Scots, and Engli≈øh thereabouts, and ≈øo the Iri≈øh to fall upon all the Engli≈øh and Scots Prote≈øtants in that Kingdome, but not to murther them in ≈øuch a ma≈ø≈øacring way, they only were to ≈øecure their per≈øons and e≈øtates, till further order, and that they
were called to an accompt for their religion, and then refu≈øing, ≈øhould ≈øuffer.

Their Plott failing in this particular, the Iri≈øh waited on, as amazed, to ≈øee the i≈ø≈øue of their Earle (as they after tearm'd him) 'twas May following before his head was taken off, and after that, the Iri≈øh Armie was disbanded, which was no ≈ømall vexation to the Iri≈øh (as may further appeare in the Iri≈øh Remon≈øtrance to his Maje≈øtie, that being their ≈øixt grievance) they mu≈øt then another way to worke, their agents being in England, they waited their return and taking their advantage of the yeare, after Harve≈øt, the 23. of October 1641. began their bloody ma≈ø≈øacre, Donnagh Mac Guire, the Lord of Eneskillings Uncle, and Hugh Mac Mahoune, the ≈øaid Lords Secretarie, and chiefe Coun≈øellour affirmed, that they ≈øhould have begun that time twelve-moneth, had the Lord of Straford returned according to expectation; and al≈øo they expre≈øt, that there were the like di≈øtempers in England, and that Plott was for the three Kingdomes, and had the Ca≈øtle of Dublin beene taken, they would have ≈øent fourtie thou≈øand men to England. Being oppo≈øed by the hearer, that he could not beleeve that the Earle had any hand in ≈øuch a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; they affirmed hee had, and was to be Lord of Ireland, as in former ages they had; and that they would not begin when they heard his head was off, but forbore till harve≈øt was in, and nights long, that they might ≈øet them≈øelves in a po≈øture of warre. For they well knew how ea≈øie it was in Summer, for England and Scotland to ≈øend an Armie to qualifie them.

Some notice may be taken of the Earles words before hee parted with his head, ≈øpeaking of a Reformation in Charracters of blood, and that there was a Cloud impending, which ≈øince hath proved too true to our wofull experience. (What will not ambitious Machavilians attempt to make them and their po≈øterity great.) Mo≈øt certaine it is by relation of tho≈øe that were about the Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour to Spaine, that about Michaelma≈ø≈øe 1640. the Je≈øuites, Prie≈øts, and Friers, in Spaine expected
to heare newes of the di≈øtempers in Ireland, (the Rebellion I meane) upon which the Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour ≈øent to the Court in England, to know the certaintie, returne was made all well and quiet, yet the ≈øaid Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour ≈øtayed in Spaine till about Michaelma≈ø≈øe 1641. all that whole yeare, the Je≈øuits, Prie≈øts, &c. expected daily to heare of di≈øturbance in Ireland: Each particular ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øidered and compared one with another, I beleeve may ≈øatisfie any rea≈øonable man, that the ≈øaid Earle mu≈øt needs have a hand in the Plott of Ireland; Sir George Ratclife may be ≈øo farre taken notice of, that he ≈øtormed very much again≈øt the Church warden of Saint Warbres Pari≈øh in Dublin; for pre≈øenting a Ma≈ø≈øe-hou≈øe that was newly erected within foure or five hou≈øes of the Ca≈øtle gate, in which Ma≈ø≈øe was frequently ≈øaid, and he Commanded the pre≈øentment to be ca≈øt forth of the Court, and never could further endure the ≈øaid Churchwarden. There is no wonder in this, for all men that knew him, might quickly di≈øcerne his inclination to that Idolatrous, Babilonian whore.

Now, ≈øince this ma≈ø≈øacring act it hath been frequently ≈øpoken by the Rebells, that what they did was by Commi≈ø≈øion, which ≈øtill they ju≈øtifie. Let all Chri≈øtians ≈øtand here amazed to behold the ce≈ø≈øation of Armes to be granted to ≈øuch Butcherly Hell-hounds, who have wallowed and embrewed their hands in the de≈øtruction of at lea≈øt two hundred thou≈øand Prote≈øtants, of men, women, and children, which will be particularly proved if occa≈øion be offered. Yet it is reported that there is Brian mac Neale, the Ferry-mans ≈øonne of Strangford in Ireland, who hath a≈ø≈øumed the name of O Neale, one of tho≈øe that at fir≈øt ≈øhould have ≈øurprized the Ca≈øtle of Dublin, and who is now made Knight and Barronet, called Sir Brian O Neale, that doth ju≈øtifie to his Maje≈øtie, that there was not above tenne per≈øons de≈øtroyed in all Vl≈øter. Againe, their Remon≈øtrance ≈øet forth, intituled, A Remon≈øtrance of Grievances pre≈øented to his mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie in the behalfe of the Catholicks of Ireland)
wherein the Rebels doe declare, and turne the whole Rebellion on the Prote≈øtants, and ≈øtand on their own iu≈øtification that what Ma≈ø≈øacries were committed were done by the Engli≈øh. Are not the≈øe a people to be had in high e≈øtimation, committing ≈øuch Acts as they did to ≈øtand out in their owne ju≈øtification & for any thing I can ≈øee as yet like to carry it ≈øo. How prevalent the Iri≈øh faction is about the Court, is ≈øufficiently app ‚Ä¢ rent, little que≈øtion their is to be made, of there obtaining a ≈øuddaine peace.

There is one thing to be taken notice of that when the Lord of Ormond marched forth this la≈øt Summer 1643. with foure thou≈øand hor≈øe, and foot, kept the randevous at Curr in Kildare, when they might have done good execution again≈øt the Enemie were kept above a fortnight in the field and Starved above three hundered of them returned (though they ≈øaw the enemies Coulours flying in the field) taking only one poore old Ca≈øtle not worth a con≈øideration, then after that, they were di≈øperced by Companies (≈øome three thou≈øand of them) into ≈ømale Garri≈øons in the pall, to ≈øecure old Ca≈øtles; a weeke before the Ce≈ø≈øation was concluded the Iri≈øh forces both of Lin≈øter Connaught, and Vl≈øter, (they well knowing when to conclude the Ce≈ø≈øation) joyned together and fell on the ≈øaid ≈ømall Garri≈øons, and de≈øtroyed many, and tooke divers pri≈øoners, po≈ø≈øe≈øt them≈øelves of a great part of Meath which ≈øtill they inioy. Oh let all Prote≈øtants either now open their eyes, or el≈øe re≈øolve to undergoe the yoake that they are not, or will not be willing to beare, when it will be to late for them, then to wi≈øh I had done this or that &c. May we not now ob≈øerve in what a Cloud ≈øtill we are under, though faire ≈øhaddows are ca≈øt before our eyes; As that the new Lord Lievtenant Marque≈ø≈øe of Ormond, hath commanded that no Papi≈øt ≈øhall be either of his retinnue, or of his Companies, in his regiment and Guard, when it may be well ob≈øerved how forward he is to give way to Papi≈øts to be tran≈øported into England, to ≈øerve again≈øt the Prote≈øtants, as al≈øo tis worth a con≈øideration (that ≈øince the
Lord of Stratfords time, and the time that Iames the Pedlar ≈øonge downe derry) the ≈øecond or Alter-like Service, hath beene omitted at Chri≈øt-Church in Dublin in the Lord Ju≈øtices time, yet now newly revived, ≈øince the Marque≈ø≈øe of Ormond received the ≈øword, how neare ≈øtill they pre≈øume to declare them≈øelves, not what they would be at, that bewitched druncken cup of fornication; let notice bee taken likewi≈øe of the ≈øecond Ratclife alias Sir Morris Eu≈øtace the chiefe Coun≈øellour of that Kingdome, that in ≈øome mea≈øure declared him≈øelfe, (one may ≈øee daylight at a little hole) there was one that had an e≈øtate in hou≈øes in Dublin, and ≈øet them to tennant, the Landlord that ≈øet them, hath beene in Rebellion at this time untill the Ce≈ø≈øation of armes, then repaired to Dublin, demanded his rents, from the tennant and arrerages, for two years pa≈øt, the tennant an≈øwered, that it had beene le≈ø≈øe charge to him to have paid his rent, then to have borne that cea≈øe and pre≈ø≈øe, and billiting of Souldiers as he did, and ≈øo declared he was unable to pay his rent, the Landlord threatned to de≈øtraine, for he ob≈øerved there was hou≈øehold ≈øtuffe left that would di≈øcharge the rent and arrerages, the tennant being thus threatned, de≈øired the oppinion of Sir Morris Eu≈øtace, and informed him his ca≈øe, who declared that he was bound to pay his rent, otherwi≈øe by the Law of the Land he might be di≈øtrained on.

This is a hard ca≈øe that Rebells ≈øhall have their rents paid them, and that many hundreds of us Prote≈øtants ruin'd (with their wives and children) in their e≈øtates by the Rebels, and are daily begging and ≈øtarving in Dublin, and other parts of that Kingdome (be≈øides tho≈øe that are forced to flie for ≈øuccour into other Kingdomes, and no reparation can be thought of, for the keeping them alive, out of their owne e≈øtates, enioyed now by the Rebells; whil≈øt our army was on foote (God ≈øo ble≈ø≈øed our poore handfull of men) that ≈øtill they had the better of the
enemy, and ≈øpoyle was gained to relieve them and others, now we all ≈øuffer, and that iu≈øtly for di≈øpairing of Gods providence to us; let the authors of the Ce≈ø≈øation looke to it; tis but in us to ob≈øerve, and morne, to ≈øee that a Ce≈ø≈øation of armes mu≈øt be yeelded unto ≈øuch Antichri≈øtian infernall Locu≈øts as they are, and no under≈øtanding for the Prote≈øtant reformed Religion, can be hearkened unto in England, our own men brought from Ireland to be made in≈øtruments again≈øt our ≈øelves; Is not this the depth of a Machavillian mi≈øtery, we may ob≈øerve the providence of the Almighty on the officers and Souldiers, (that did doe gallant Service again≈øt the Iri≈øh Rebells) which were ≈øent into England how ≈øoone it plea≈øed the Lord to declare, he was not well plea≈øed with theit comming ≈øhewing his hand on them at Nantwitch.

Now faire oppertunity may the Iri≈øh have to playe their after gaine, as they have ≈øufficiently envited and ≈øet forth in print from Waterford. Entituled, Admoni≈ø≈øions by the ≈øupreame Coun≈øell of the confederate Catholicks of Ireland: To all his Maje≈øties faithfull, loyall Subjects of the three Kingdomes, of England, Ireland, and Scotland, again≈øt a ≈øolemne League and Covenant framed by the Malignant party, in the Parliament of England; as al≈øo a Declaration of the Engli≈øh Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament wherein they en≈øite, not only their owne Nation to ≈øtand to their Arms offen≈øive and Defen≈øive, but envite them to a timely and a fit prevention; as al≈øo envite all Romi≈øh Catholicke Kings, to take notice how far they are engaged in it; as much as if they ≈øhould ≈øay to their Countrimen, play your after game, take a fit time to cutt all the re≈øt of the Prote≈øtants throats and to envite other Princes to fall upon the Ma≈ø≈øacring of all the Prote≈øtants, within their verdge.

Thus we find how active they are at the pen let us looke a little further, & conclude what their intentions are, as doth evedently
appeare by their diligence, in ≈ølacking no time to ≈øet forward their intended project, how bu≈øie they (the Iri≈øh) have beene in procuring Armes and Ammunition ≈øince the Ce≈ø≈øation. Sir Pierce Crosbie, who about the time of Concluding the Ce≈ø≈øation, brought over with him to Waterford, (for the Rebels) five thou≈øand Armes and Ammunition.
Againe, the Popes Nuntio (who is there frequent with them (brought over Trea≈øure to maintaine the warre, as is ≈øaid fiftie thou≈øand pounds.

And now la≈øtly, about Candlemas there landed two Agents from Forraign parts, who brought over with them to Waterford ≈øtore both of Armes and Amunition, and much more is brought daily, though we cannot di≈øcover every particular; Doth not this demon≈øtrate unto us their intent, and how cautious they were in the concluding of the Ce≈ø≈øation (that provi≈øo) to have liberty to buy Armes, and Ammunition where they plea≈øed, either in that Kingdome, or from Forraigne parts, how frequent they are at Dublin, in buying Armes from the Cutlers at what rate ≈øoever, without ay interruption, that a good Sword no Cutler can keepe by him, the Iri≈øh Gentrie buy them ≈øo fa≈øt, and give any rates for them; What advantage is this again≈øt us, they arming them≈øelves, and we di≈øarming our ≈øelves, by ≈øending our men and Armes, and Artillerie out of that Kingdome to maintaine warre our again≈øt our ≈øelves, how in≈øolent the Iri≈øh Nobilitie and Gentrie, doe now ≈øhew them≈øelves again≈øt our Engli≈øh Nobilitie and Gentry at Dublin, 'tis apparant, as in the Ca≈øe betweene the young Lord Moore. and the Lord Tate, as al≈øo in the Ca≈øe betweene Sir Thomas Arm≈øtrong, and Captaine Flowre, on one part Prote≈øtants; and Cornet Mac Gragh and Routh Papi≈øts, of the other part, the Papi≈øts taking opportunitie in the ≈øtreets of Dublin to affront our Prote≈øtants, Lords and Gentrie; they doe well to demon≈øtrate unto us, that when their ≈øecond Plott is to be ≈øet in agitation, may in Dublin
begin upon ≈øuch like Quarrels in the ≈øtreets, thereby to take occa≈øion for the ≈øecond cutting of throats, and once being pa≈øt to flouri≈øh it over, and ≈øay 'twas ≈øome drunken quarrell or other, for at this in≈øtant, Dublin may take it ≈øelfe, the major part being Iri≈øh now in it.

To Conclude, now the Scotti≈øh Armie are re≈øolved to depart from the North of Ireland, as already appeares, three Regiments are wafted over into Scotland, (which maketh ≈øtill for the Iri≈øh) and to bring to a period their Je≈øuiticall Plott, ≈øo as the Iri≈øh may the better performe their offer to ≈øend away tenne thou≈øand of their chiefe Souldiers, under the Command of experienced Commanders, to keepe the Prote≈øtants in Armes in other Kingdomes, either in England or Scotland; Oh! that we might in ≈øome mea≈øure u≈øe the Pollicies of the Antient Romans, or of late Queene Elizabeth of famous Memorie did, who when the Spaniards ≈øtrove to envade England, did afford ≈øome aide unto the Hollander to keepe the Spaniards on worke at home, by which ≈øhe pre≈øerved her Kingdomes (under Gods Providence) from being a Seat of warre: So if timely prevented by England and Scotland, to keepe the warre afoote in Ireland, to prevent further mi≈øchiefe, (which is like to en≈øue, if the Iri≈øh breake forth into other Kingdomes) and ≈øo turne the Sword into their owne bo≈øomes: which that wee may, the Lord of Ho≈øts enable us to doe.

Here now it is manife≈øt that the Iri≈øh have obtained not only their fir≈øt reque≈øt de≈øired in their Remon≈øtrance, which was to have one placed in chiefe Authoritie, of Honour and Fortune, approved by His Maje≈øtie, and acceptable to the Rebells, (which proveth to be the Marque≈ø≈øe of Ormond) but al≈øo the other to have a free Parliament held there, and and an Act of oblivion to be made for their Rebellion; and Poynings Act to be repealed: and there the Rebells to hold their Parliament; which is reported His Maje≈øtie hath yeelded unto, by granting
Pardon to the Iri≈øh Rebells. Lately, at Oxford Confirmed under the Great Seale of England, for Pardoning all Murders and Robberies what≈øoever, and authorizing a new Parliament to be called there according to the Rebells de≈øires, ≈øo that now we mu≈øt expect they will performe their promi≈øe to his Maje≈øtie in ≈øending ten thou≈øand men and Armes into England; Yet we know there is a King of Kings, that can turne the wi≈ødome of the wi≈øe into fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe.
Publi≈øhed according to Order.

div.head: A POSTSCRIPT TO THE READER.
div.p: CHri≈øtian Reader be plea≈øed in this trackt to con≈øider the depth of an adver≈øary, that aimes at the de≈øtruction of the true Prote≈øtant Religion, had the Plott held according to their je≈øuiticall intent, by this time there would have beene few left, to ob≈øerve for future, their infernall projects, the Almighty who pre≈øerved Io≈øeph from the malicious intent of his brethren (to be under him) the in≈øtrument to pre≈øerve them from calamity; is the ≈øame who will deliver them that tru≈øt in him, from that which might prove wor≈øe, then the Egyptian Bondage, which every true Chri≈øtian is bound to endeavour a prevention, and to take no exceptions, though they are envited by him that hath beene and is a ≈øufferer (for Chri≈øts cau≈øe) and his Countreys ≈øake.
